1.q_string:
The combined form of first and second laws of thermodynamics is given by ( \(P=\)

Pressure, \({V}=\) Volume, \({T}=\) Temperature, \({U}=\) Internal energy, \({S}=\) Entropy, \({Q}={Quantity}\) of heat):
\(3000 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat is added to a system and \(2500 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done by the system. What is the change in internal energy of the system?

An ideal gas heat engine operates in Carnot's cycle between \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) It absorbs \(6 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~J}\) at high temperature. The amount of heat converted into work is:

An ideal gas is expanded isothermally from a volume \(V_{1}\) to volume \(V_{2}\) and then, compressed adiabatically to original volume \(V_{1}\). The initial pressure is \(P_{1}\) and the final pressure is \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\). If the net work done is \(\mathrm{W}\), then:

\(5\) mole of oxygen are heated at constant volume from \(10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). What will be the change in the internal energy of gas? The molar heat of oxygen at constant pressure, \(C_{P}=7.03 \mathrm{cal}\) \(\mathrm{mol}^{-1} \operatorname{deg}^{-1}\) and \(\mathrm{R}=8.31 \mathrm{~J} \quad \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{deg}^{-1}\).
A monoatomic gas is supplied heat Q very slowly, keeping the pressure constant. The work done by the gas will be:

A sample of \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) of monoatomic Helium(assume ideal) is taken through the process \(\mathrm{ABC}\) and another sample of \(2 \mathrm{~kg}\) of the same gas is taken through the process \(\mathrm{ADC}\). Given, relative molecular mass of \(\mathrm{Helium}=4\).

What is the temperature of Helium in each of the states \(\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}, \mathrm{C}\) and \(\mathrm{D}\)?



The temperature of state \(C\) is

A system goes from A to B via two processes I and II as shown in the figure. If \(\Delta U_{1}\) and \(\Delta \mathrm{U}_{2}\) are the changes in internal energies in processes I and II, respectively, then:
A Carnot engine takes \(300\) calories of heat from a source at \(500 \mathrm{~K}\) and rejects \(150\) calories of heat to the sink. The temperature of the sink is:
What is the coefficient of performance of a refrigerator between 10°C and 42°C?

q_option: Whole of the heat can be converted into mechanical energy
A refrigerator can reduce the temperature to absolute zero
1.q_string: The second law of thermodynamics implies that:

A diatomic ideal gas is heated at constant volume until the pressure is doubled and again heated at constant pressure until the volume is doubled. The average molar heat capacity for the whole process is:

In a thermodynamic process, pressure of a fixed mass of gas is changed in such a manner that the gas releases \(30 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat and \(8 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done on the gas. If the initial internal energy of the gas is \(40 \mathrm{~J}\), what will be the final internal energy?
Which of the following graphs correctly represent the variation of \(\beta=-\frac{d V / d p}{V}\) with \(p\) for an ideai gas at constant temperature?
In the process depicted below, there is no loss of heat from A to B. The process is:

An ideal gas is contained in a thermally insulated and rigid container and it is heated through a resistance \(100 \Omega\) by passing a current of \(1 \mathrm{~A}\) for five minutes, then change in internal energy of the gas is:

In a thermodynamic process pressure of a fixed mass of a gas is changed in such a manner that the gas releases \(20 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat and \(8 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done on the gas if the initial internal energy of the gas was \(30 \mathrm{~J}\). The final internal energy wilI be:
The state of a thermodynamic system is represented by:

An ideal gas is taken through the cycle \(\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}\) as shown in the figure below. If the net heat supplied to the gas in the cycle is \(5 \mathrm{~J}\), the work done by the gas in the process \(\mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}\) is:
A thermodynamical system is changed from state \(\left(P_{1}, V_{1}\right)\) to \(\left(P_{2}, V_{2}\right)\) by two different processes. The quantity which will remain the same is:

q_option: A is true, but B is false.
A is false, but B is true.
1.q_string:
Consider the following statements (A) and (B). Read the statements and mark the correct answer.

A.  First law of thermodynamics specifies the conditions under which a body can use its heat energy to produce work.

B.  Second law of thermodynamics states that heat always flows from a hot body to a cold body.

Consider the following statements:

1. Zeroth law of thermodynamics is related to temperature

2. Entropy is related to first law of thermodynamics

3. Internal energy of an ideal gas is a function of temperature and pressure

4. Van der Waals equation is related to an ideal gas

Which of the above statements is/are correct ?

A litre of hydrogen at \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(10^{6}\) dyne \(\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\) pressure expands isothermally until its volume is doubled and then, adiabatically until its volume is redoubled. Find the final pressure of the gas. Given \(\gamma=1.4\).

\(1 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) of gas is compressed suddenly at atmospheric pressure and temperature \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) such that its temperature becomes \(627^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). the final pressure of the gas (if \(\gamma=1.5\) ) will be:

q_option: The substance undergoing a reversible change must at all instances be in thermodynamic equilibrium with its surroundings
There should not be any loss of energy due to conduction, convection or radiation during the cycle
There should not be any loss of energy due to conduction, convection or radiation during the cycle of operation
1.q_string: Which of the following is a necessary condition for a process to be reversible?
